citation.article-title: Mameliella alba gen. nov., sp. nov., a marine bacterium of the Roseobacter clade in the order Rhodobacterales
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Mameliella alba sp. nov.
Mameliella alba (al′ba. L. fem. adj. alba white).
Exhibits the following properties in addition to those given in the genus description.
Cells are 2.0–3.2 μm long and 0.7–0.9 μm wide.
Small (about 0.5–1.5 mm) colonies are produced on RO medium after incubation at 25 °C for 3–5 days.
Colonies are smooth, convex and opaque.
Growth occurs at 10–30 °C, at pH 6.0–9.0 and in the presence of 1.0–10 % NaCl; optimal growth occurs at 25 °C, at pH 8.0 and in the presence of 1.0–2.0 % NaCl.
Negative for hydrolysis of Tween 80, casein, aerobic nitrite reduction, methyl red test and Voges–Proskauer reaction.
Results for utilization of various substrates as sole carbon sources, and other differential characteristics, are listed in Table 1.

Utilizes l-malic acid, d-malonic acid, sodium d-gluconate, acetic acid, citric acid, lactic acid, d-sorbitol, d-mannitol, glycerol, myo-inositol, cellobiose, trehalose dihydrate, maltose, d-glucose, sucrose, d-xylose, l-alanine and l-arginine, but not l-sorbose, lysine, glycine, α-d-lactose, d-fructose, d-xylose or l-threonine.
Acid is produced from d-glucose, sucrose, d-sorbitol, trehalose and maltose.
Sensitive to gentamicin, ciprofloxacin, clindamycin, chloramphenicol, streptomycin, cefoperazone and ampicillin.
The predominant fatty acid is C18 : 1ω7c; significant amounts of C18 : 0, C12 : 1 3-OH, C16 : 0 and 11-methyl C18 : 1ω7c are also present.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 63.7 mol% (Tm).
The type strain, JLT354-WT (=LMG 24665T=CGMCC 1.7290T), was isolated from surface water of the South China Sea in China.
